Welcome to CodeClan Simon Says (aka C.S.S)!

Where a website tells you what to do!

The purpose of this page is to allow people to practice their CSS skills. Below will be a number of elements which will tell you how they want to be styled using CSS. You have been provided a style.css file to write your styling in.

Some of these elements will specify that they want to be targeted using a class, an id, or just element selectors.

Note: Ignore the ignore.css file; it's used to lay out the page.

Colours

  • Make my text green using a class.
  • Make my text red using an id.
  • Make my background colour blue and my text white using any kind of selector.
  • Make my background colour purple and my text white using element selectors.
    (#colours li:last-child { ... })

Font

  • Make my text bold using an element selector.
  • Make my text italic using a class.
  • Make my text a different font using any kind of selector.
  • make my text bigger using a class.
  • Make my text underlined, bold, and a different font using any kind of selector.
  • Make my wider than normal using any kind of selector.

Shadows

  • Give my text a shadow of any colour and size using a class.
  • Give me a box shadow of any colour and size using a class.
  • Give me a small, tight, grey box shadow using a class.
  • Give my text any shadow, and give me any box shadow; using a class.

Shadow Documentation

  • box-shadow
  • text-shadow

Combinations (harder)

Use classes for all of these. Check the page after each requirement to see what's changed.

  • Make my text 'sans-serif' font, large, and white. Increase the letter spacing slightly. Give me a dark grey background. Give me a border-radius of 8px. Give me a thin dark orange border. Give me a padding of 15px. Give me a grey box-shadow.
  • Make my text large. Make these specific words underlined and italic. Give me a padding of 30px. Give me this shadow: box-shadow: grey inset 0 0 15px 0;. Play around with the shadow property values to experiment with the property.
  • Use me as your experiment: play around with properties however you want. I recommend looking into background gradients. The following text exists only to make this element larger so you can better see your stylings:
